> [Seairth Jacobs]
> This has been a very interesting conversation...
> 1) I GET http://my.bank/access.  The server returns an HTTP 
> Authentication challenge...

I am the "OP" and I am surprised how my original question turned 
into this long conversation :-)

I was just asking how to solve a CGI programming problem with Python 
in a RESTful way!

I can not do HTTP authentication from a Python CGI script, can I?  I 
tried to look for examples or to figure it out but I have been 
unsuccessful.  And then somebody explained to me that HTTP auth. is 
not used by banks etc. on the internet, because it is not secure 
enough.  For my civilization like game HTTP auth. could be secure 
enough, but oh well, I don't know how to implement it from a CGI 
script anyway.
  
So I was thinking about setting up the "login" page with HTTPS and 
this then calls a CGI script generating a "sessionID" passed along 
with HIDDEN HTML FORM parameters on every next page, and then all 
the next pages don't need SSL.  The nice thing for me is then that I 
don't have to change source code when the SSL part is turned on 
later.  I can develop it using Apache on my laptop (without SSL).
Or is there a more RESTful way to do it?
